messageBody:
>So said Paul Zabelin on 2003-06-02 --------------------
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
>wrote:
>> >So said Paul Zabelin on 2003-05-28 --------------------
>>
>>http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/files/src/VectorExceptionTest.jav
>a
>> Perhaps, but this technique makes it difficult to see which code
>blocks should throw which exceptions.
>Probably we can prepare exceptional conditions in setUp and
>implement "test..." methods as 1 line callers of exception causing
>method of class undergoing testing.

I need to define the exception I expect inside the test method, otherwise I cannot read the test.

>>I have to bounce back and forth between the test and the suite()
>method to determine which exceptions I should expect the code to
>throw. That's distracting.
>Totally agree. Cann't we use reflection to pass on information about
>exception and use TestCase(String name) constructor. I am writing a
>shot example for it, check on
>http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/files/.

I'll look when you're done, but I have my doubts.

>> The assertThrows pattern makes that clearer, even if it results in
>more code.
>I tried to use assertThrows, but it looks lot less cleaner, then
>normal test.

If your eyes can get past the extra syntax crap that Java forces you to write, it's cleaner!

assertThrows(NullPointerException.class, {
Object object = null;
null.clone();
});

Pretend that Java allows you to create a block of code by simply putting statements between braces, like I did above. Do you really find ExceptionTestCase to be clearer than that?

It's just unfortunate that Java forces me to do this.

assertThrows(NullPointerException.class, new Block() {
public void execute() throws Exception {
Object object = null;
null.clone();
}
});

Just ignore the method declaration and it's almost as clear.

Take care.
